label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: A clock or a timepiece is a device used to measure and indicate time.
simplified: A clock or timepiece is a piece of equipment that measures time.
split: ['A clock or timepiece is a piece of equipment that measures time.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: The clock is one of the oldest human inventions, meeting the need to measure intervals of time shorter than the natural units: the day, the lunar month, year and galactic year.
simplified: The clock is one of the oldest human inventions. People needed a way to measure time that was shorter than the amount of time in the day, month, year and year.
split: ['The clock is one of the oldest human inventions', 'People needed a way to measure time that was shorter than the amount of time in the day, month, year and year.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Devices operating on several physical processes have been used over the millennia.
simplified: Several different physical processes have been used over the millennia.
split: ['Several different physical processes have been used over the millennia.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Some predecessors to the modern clock may be considered as "clocks" that are based on movement in nature: A sundial shows the time by displaying the position of a shadow on a flat surface.
simplified: Some predecessors to the modern clock may be considered as "clocks": A sundial shows the time by showing the position of a shadow on a flat surface, as the sun sets and the sun rises.
split: ['Some predecessors to the modern clock may be considered as "clocks": A sundial shows the time by showing the position of a shadow on a flat surface, as the sun sets and the sun rises.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: There is a range of duration timers, a well-known example being the hourglass.
simplified: There are different types of timers. An example of a timer is the hourglass.
split: ['There are different types of timers', 'An example of a timer is the hourglass.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Water clocks, along with the sundials, are possibly the oldest time-measuring instruments.
simplified: Water clocks, along with sundials, are probably the oldest instruments to measure time.
split: ['Water clocks, along with sundials, are probably the oldest instruments to measure time.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: A major advance occurred with the invention of the verge escapement, which made possible the first mechanical clocks around 1300 in Europe, which kept time with oscillating timekeepers like balance wheels.
simplified: The first mechanical clocks were made around 1300 in Europe. They had wheels that moved with the time, and kept time with something like a balance wheel, but they did not work very well.
split: ['The first mechanical clocks were made around 1300 in Europe', 'They had wheels that moved with the time, and kept time with something like a balance wheel, but they did not work very well.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Traditionally, in horology, the term clock was used for a striking clock, while a clock that did not strike the hours audibly was called a timepiece.
simplified: A clock that does not strike the hours by itself is called a striking clock. A clock that does not strike at all is called a silent clock.
split: ['A clock that does not strike the hours by itself is called a striking clock', 'A clock that does not strike at all is called a silent clock.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: This distinction is no longer made.
simplified: This difference is no longer made.
split: ['This difference is no longer made.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Watches and other timepieces that can be carried on one's person are usually not referred to as clocks.
simplified: Watches and other timepieces are usually not called clocks because they can be carried on one's person.
split: ["Watches and other timepieces are usually not called clocks because they can be carried on one's person."]

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Spring-driven clocks appeared during the 15th century.
simplified: Spring-driven clocks were first seen in the 15th century.
split: ['Spring-driven clocks were first seen in the 15th century.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: During the 15th and 16th centuries, clockmaking flourished.
simplified: During the 16th century, many people made clocks.
split: ['During the 16th century, many people made clocks.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: The next development in accuracy occurred after 1656 with the invention of the pendulum clock by Christiaan Huygens.
simplified: After 1656 a very good clock was made by Christiaan Huygens. This was a pendulum clock and it was very accurate.
split: ['After 1656 a very good clock was made by Christiaan Huygens', 'This was a pendulum clock and it was very accurate.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: A major stimulus to improving the accuracy and reliability of clocks was the importance of precise time-keeping for navigation.
simplified: The most important reason to make clocks more accurate was because it was important to know the time for navigation.
split: ['The most important reason to make clocks more accurate was because it was important to know the time for navigation.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: The mechanism of a timepiece with a series of gears driven by a spring or weights is referred to as clockwork; the term is used by extension for a similar mechanism not used in a timepiece.
simplified: The mechanism of a timepiece with a series of gears driven by a spring is called clockwork. The term "timepiece" is also used to refer to a collection of timepieces.
split: ['The mechanism of a timepiece with a series of gears driven by a spring is called clockwork', 'The term "timepiece" is also used to refer to a collection of timepieces.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: The electric clock was patented in 1840, and electronic clocks were introduced in the 20th century, becoming widespread with the development of small battery-powered semiconductor devices.
simplified: The electric clock was patented in 1840, and electronic clocks were first used in the 20th century. In the 20th century, small battery-powered devices started to be used.
split: ['The electric clock was patented in 1840, and electronic clocks were first used in the 20th century', 'In the 20th century, small battery-powered devices started to be used.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: The timekeeping element in every modern clock is a harmonic oscillator, a physical object (resonator) that vibrates or oscillates at a particular frequency.
simplified: The timekeeping element in every modern clock is a harmonic oscillator. The harmonic oscillator is a physical object that can be made to vibrate.
split: ['The timekeeping element in every modern clock is a harmonic oscillator', 'The harmonic oscillator is a physical object that can be made to vibrate.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: This object can be a pendulum, a tuning fork, a quartz crystal, or the vibration of electrons in atoms as they emit microwaves.
simplified: This object can be a pendulum, a tuning fork, a quartz crystal (a crystal that changes color when it is struck by light).
split: ['This object can be a pendulum, a tuning fork, a quartz crystal (a crystal that changes color when it is struck by light).']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Clocks have different ways of displaying the time.
simplified: There are many different types of clocks.
split: ['There are many different types of clocks.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Analog clocks indicate time with a traditional clock face, with moving hands.
simplified: Analog clocks show time by moving their hands. A digital clock does the same.
split: ['Analog clocks show time by moving their hands', 'A digital clock does the same.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Digital clocks display a numeric representation of time.
simplified: Digital clocks use numbers to show the time.
split: ['Digital clocks use numbers to show the time.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Two numbering systems are in use: 24-hour time notation and 12-hour notation.
simplified: There are two different time systems. One is 24-hour time notation.
split: ['There are two different time systems', 'One is 24-hour time notation.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: Most digital clocks use electronic mechanisms and LCD, LED, or VFD displays.
simplified: Most digital clocks use an electronic mechanism, but not all do so well.
split: ['Most digital clocks use an electronic mechanism, but not all do so well.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: For the blind and for use over telephones, speaking clocks state the time audibly in words.
simplified: For the blind and people who can not see, speaking clocks say the time with words.
split: ['For the blind and people who can not see, speaking clocks say the time with words.']

label: wiki-clock-en.txt
original: There are also clocks for the blind that have displays that can be read by touch.
simplified: There are also special clocks for the blind. They can be read by touch.
split: ['There are also special clocks for the blind', 'They can be read by touch.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin is the capital and largest city of Germany by both area and population.
simplified: Berlin is the capital city of Germany. It is the largest city in Germany.
split: ['Berlin is the capital city of Germany', 'It is the largest city in Germany.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Its 3.7 million inhabitants make it the European Union's most populous city, according to population within city limits.
simplified: With 3.7 million people living there, it is the most populous city in the European Union, by population.
split: ['With 3.7 million people living there, it is the most populous city in the European Union, by population.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: One of Germany's sixteen constituent states, Berlin is surrounded by the State of Brandenburg and contiguous with Potsdam, Brandenburg's capital.
simplified: Berlin is the capital of the German state of Berlin. The state of Brandenburg lies to the west of Berlin, and Potsdam is its capital.
split: ['Berlin is the capital of the German state of Berlin', 'The state of Brandenburg lies to the west of Berlin, and Potsdam is its capital.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin's urban area, which has a population of around 4.5 million, is the second most populous urban area in Germany after the Ruhr.
simplified: Around 4.5 million people live in the urban area of Berlin. It is the second largest urban area in Germany after the Ruhr Area.
split: ['Around 4.5 million people live in the urban area of Berlin', 'It is the second largest urban area in Germany after the Ruhr Area.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: The Berlin-Brandenburg capital region has over six million inhabitants and is Germany's third-largest metropolitan region after the Rhine-Ruhr and Rhine-Main regions.
simplified: Berlin-Brandenburg has over six million people living in it. It is the third largest city in Germany (after the Rhine-Ruhr region and the Rhine-Main region).
split: ['Berlin-Brandenburg has over six million people living in it', 'It is the third largest city in Germany (after the Rhine-Ruhr region and the Rhine-Main region).']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin straddles the banks of the Spree, which flows into the Havel (a tributary of the Elbe) in the western borough of Spandau.
simplified: Berlin is located on the Spree river. This river flows into the Havel in the western part of the city in Spandau.
split: ['Berlin is located on the Spree river', 'This river flows into the Havel in the western part of the city in Spandau.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Among the city's main topographical features are the many lakes in the western and southeastern boroughs formed by the Spree, Havel and Dahme, the largest of which is Lake Müggelsee.
simplified: Among the city's main topographical features are the many lakes in the western and southeastern parts of the city. The largest of these lakes is called Lake Müggelsee.
split: ["Among the city's main topographical features are the many lakes in the western and southeastern parts of the city", 'The largest of these lakes is called Lake Müggelsee.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Due to its location in the European Plain, Berlin is influenced by a temperate seasonal climate.
simplified: Because Berlin is in the European Plain, the climate changes from time to time.
split: ['Because Berlin is in the European Plain, the climate changes from time to time.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: About one-third of the city's area is composed of forests, parks, gardens, rivers, canals and lakes.
simplified: About one-third of the city's area is made up of forests. The city also has many parks and gardens.
split: ["About one-third of the city's area is made up of forests", 'The city also has many parks and gardens.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: The city lies in the Central German dialect area, the Berlin dialect being a variant of the Lusatian-New Marchian dialects.
simplified: The city is in the Central German dialect area. The Berlin dialect is different from many other dialects in Germany.
split: ['The city is in the Central German dialect area', 'The Berlin dialect is different from many other dialects in Germany.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: First documented in the 13th century and at the crossing of two important historic trade routes, Berlin became the capital of the Margraviate of Brandenburg (1417–1701), the Kingdom of Prussia (1701–1918), the German Empire (1871–1918), the Weimar Republic (1919–1933), and the Third Reich (1933–1945).
simplified: Berlin became the capital of the Margraviate of Brandenburg (1417 â "1701), the Kingdom of Prussia (1701 â" 1818), the German Empire (1871 â" 1818), the Weimar Republic (1919 â "1933), and the Third Reich (1933 â" 1945). It was also the capital of the Soviet Union (1933 â" 1945).
split: ['Berlin became the capital of the Margraviate of Brandenburg (1417 â "1701), the Kingdom of Prussia (1701 â" 1818), the German Empire (1871 â" 1818), the Weimar Republic (1919 â "1933), and the Third Reich (1933 â" 1945)', 'It was also the capital of the Soviet Union (1933 â" 1945).']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin in the 1920s was the third-largest municipality in the world.
simplified: Berlin was the world's third largest city in the 1920s.
split: ["Berlin was the world's third largest city in the 1920s."]

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: After World War II and its subsequent occupation by the victorious countries, the city was divided; West Berlin became a de facto exclave of West Germany, surrounded by the Berlin Wall (from August 1961 to November 1989) and East German territory.
simplified: After World War II, the countries that won the war took control of the city. West Berlin was taken by the United States, and East Berlin became a de facto part of West Germany, surrounded by the Berlin Wall from 1961 to 1989.
split: ['After World War II, the countries that won the war took control of the city', 'West Berlin was taken by the United States, and East Berlin became a de facto part of West Germany, surrounded by the Berlin Wall from 1961 to 1989.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: East Berlin was declared capital of East Germany, while Bonn became the West German capital.
simplified: East Berlin became the capital of East Germany, and Bonn became the capital of West Germany.
split: ['East Berlin became the capital of East Germany, and Bonn became the capital of West Germany.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Following German reunification in 1990, Berlin once again became the capital of all of Germany.
simplified: When Germany was reunited in 1990, Berlin became the capital of all of Germany again.
split: ['When Germany was reunited in 1990, Berlin became the capital of all of Germany again.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin is a world city of culture, politics, media and science.
simplified: Berlin is a very important city for culture and science.
split: ['Berlin is a very important city for culture and science.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Its economy is based on high-tech firms and the service sector, encompassing a diverse range of creative industries, research facilities, media corporations and convention venues.
simplified: Its economy is based on high-tech companies and the service sector. The city also has many different types of businesses, research facilities, media companies and convention venues.
split: ['Its economy is based on high-tech companies and the service sector', 'The city also has many different types of businesses, research facilities, media companies and convention venues.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin serves as a continental hub for air and rail traffic and has a highly complex public transportation network.
simplified: Berlin is the biggest city in Germany. It has a large public transportation network, and many international airports.
split: ['Berlin is the biggest city in Germany', 'It has a large public transportation network, and many international airports.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: The metropolis is a popular tourist destination.
simplified: The city is a popular tourist destination.
split: ['The city is a popular tourist destination.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Significant industries also include IT, pharmaceuticals, biomedical engineering, clean tech, biotechnology, construction and electronics.
simplified: Important industries also include IT, construction, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, clean tech, and medical engineering.
split: ['Important industries also include IT, construction, pharmaceuticals, biotechnology, clean tech, and medical engineering.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Berlin is home to world-renowned universities such as the Humboldt University, the Technical University, the Free University, the University of the Arts, ESMT Berlin, the Hertie School, and Bard College Berlin.
simplified: There are many universities in Berlin, for example the Humboldt University, the Free University, the Technical University, the Free University of Berlin and the Technical University of Berlin.
split: ['There are many universities in Berlin, for example the Humboldt University, the Free University, the Technical University, the Free University of Berlin and the Technical University of Berlin.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Its Zoological Garden is the most visited zoo in Europe and one of the most popular worldwide.
simplified: Its Zoological Garden is the world's most popular zoo. It is visited by many people.
split: ["Its Zoological Garden is the world's most popular zoo", 'It is visited by many people.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: With Babelsberg being the world's first large-scale movie studio complex, Berlin is an increasingly popular location for international film productions.
simplified: Babelsberg was the world's first large-scale movie studio complex. Because of this, lots of movies are made in Berlin all the time.
split: ["Babelsberg was the world's first large-scale movie studio complex", 'Because of this, lots of movies are made in Berlin all the time.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: The city is well known for its festivals, diverse architecture, nightlife, contemporary arts and a very high quality of living.
simplified: The city is well known for its festivals. It is also known for its different architecture, nightlife and high quality of living.
split: ['The city is well known for its festivals', 'It is also known for its different architecture, nightlife and high quality of living.']

label: wiki-berlin-en.txt
original: Since the 2000s Berlin has seen the emergence of a cosmopolitan entrepreneurial scene.
simplified: Since the 2000s a lot of people from different countries live in Berlin.
split: ['Since the 2000s a lot of people from different countries live in Berlin.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Despite the omicron variant, Europe's ski resorts are fairly busy.
simplified: Even though it is not the same, Europe's ski resorts are very busy.
split: ["Even though it is not the same, Europe's ski resorts are very busy."]

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Austria is seeing a disappointing season, but in Switzerland visitor numbers are exceeding pre-pandemic levels.
simplified: Austria is having a bad season, but in Switzerland visitor numbers are higher than they were before.
split: ['Austria is having a bad season, but in Switzerland visitor numbers are higher than they were before.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Lifts at a standstill, empty mountain chalets and hotels — this is what the ski season looked like in large parts of Europe last year.
simplified: Empty mountain chalets and hotels, lifts stopped, this is what the ski season looked like in large parts of Europe last year.
split: ['Empty mountain chalets and hotels, lifts stopped, this is what the ski season looked like in large parts of Europe last year.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Some ski resorts in Austria and Germany, for example, didn't open for a single day — a disaster for the tourism industry.
simplified: Some ski resorts in Austria and Germany, for example, did not open for a single day because of the weather.
split: ['Some ski resorts in Austria and Germany, for example, did not open for a single day because of the weather.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: This year, however, cable car companies and hoteliers were able to breathe a sigh of relief.
simplified: This year, however, hoteliers and cable car companies can breathe a sigh of relief.
split: ['This year, however, hoteliers and cable car companies can breathe a sigh of relief.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Despite the rapid spread of the omicron variant, skiing was and is permitted everywhere, albeit under strict conditions.
simplified: Despite the fast spread of the omicron version, skiing is still allowed in some places, but only under certain rules.
split: ['Despite the fast spread of the omicron version, skiing is still allowed in some places, but only under certain rules.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: "Above all we are very happy that the lifts are open again after the 2020/2021 winter lockdown," Carolin Kunzmann of the Bayerische Zugspitzbahn told DW.
simplified: "Above all we are very happy that the lifts are open again after the 2020/2021 winter lockdown," said Bayerische Zugspitzbahn spokeswoman Carolin Kunzmann.
split: ['"Above all we are very happy that the lifts are open again after the 2020/2021 winter lockdown," said Bayerische Zugspitzbahn spokeswoman Carolin Kunzmann.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: However, she also said that visitor numbers have remained lower than before the pandemic.
simplified: However, she also said that visitor numbers are still lower than before the crisis.
split: ['However, she also said that visitor numbers are still lower than before the crisis.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: In the areas around Germany's highest mountain, as in many ski areas in the country, the so-called 2G rule applies.
simplified: In the areas around Germany's highest mountain, so-called 2G rules apply, but some people do not follow them.
split: ["In the areas around Germany's highest mountain, so-called 2G rules apply, but some people do not follow them."]

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: "2G" stands for "geimpft oder genesen" — vaccinated or recovered.
simplified: "2G" stands for "geimpft oder genesen". This means "vaccinated".
split: ['"2G" stands for "geimpft oder genesen"', 'This means "vaccinated".']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: "Every guest is checked at the base station or at the ticket office," Kunzmann said.
simplified: "Every guest is checked at the ticket office or base station," Kunzmann said.
split: ['"Every guest is checked at the ticket office or base station," Kunzmann said.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: "Only after proof of vaccination or recovery has been presented will their ski pass be activated."
simplified: "Only after they have shown proof of recovery or vaccination will their ski pass be activated."
split: ['"Only after they have shown proof of recovery or vaccination will their ski pass be activated."']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Although this has led to longer waiting times, especially in the high season during the Christmas vacations, the approach has generally worked well.
simplified: This has led to longer waiting times, especially during the high season, but the approach has generally worked well in most cases.
split: ['This has led to longer waiting times, especially during the high season, but the approach has generally worked well in most cases.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: In addition, FFP2 masks are still mandatory in indoor areas, queuing areas, cable cars and ski lifts.
simplified: In addition, FFP2 masks are still required in indoor areas, ski lifts and cable cars.
split: ['In addition, FFP2 masks are still required in indoor areas, ski lifts and cable cars.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Austria also has strict rules for winter sports enthusiasts.
simplified: Austria also has its own rules about winter sports.
split: ['Austria also has its own rules about winter sports.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: The 2G rule and FFP2 masks are also standard practice here.
simplified: The 2G rule and FFP2 masks are also common here.
split: ['The 2G rule and FFP2 masks are also common here.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: The country was in lockdown until mid-December, due to soaring infection numbers.
simplified: The country was in a state of emergency until mid-December. The numbers were high.
split: ['The country was in a state of emergency until mid-December', 'The numbers were high.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: The Robert Koch Institute declared Austria a high-risk area, and the German Foreign Ministry accordingly issued a travel warning.
simplified: The Robert Koch Institute said that Austria was a high-risk area. The German Foreign Ministry said people should not travel there.
split: ['The Robert Koch Institute said that Austria was a high-risk area', 'The German Foreign Ministry said people should not travel there.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Many guests, especially from Germany, were understandably put off.
simplified: Many people, especially from Germany, have been put off.
split: ['Many people, especially from Germany, have been put off.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: 26% fewer holidaymakers than before the pandemic arrived from the neighboring country, according to estimates by the Austrian hoteliers' association ÖHV.
simplified: 26% fewer holidaymakers have come to Austria because of the disease, according to the Austrian hoteliers' association ÖHV.
split: ["26% fewer holidaymakers have come to Austria because of the disease, according to the Austrian hoteliers' association ÖHV."]

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: But still, the clear majority of tourists visiting Austria are from Germany.
simplified: However, the majority of people visiting Austria come from Germany.
split: ['However, the majority of people visiting Austria come from Germany.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: In January, the occupancy rate of Austrian hotels was around one third, which, according to the ÖHV, is "too little to operate economically."
simplified: In January, the occupancy rate of Austrian hotels was around one third. According to the ÖHV, this is "too little to make money."
split: ['In January, the occupancy rate of Austrian hotels was around one third', 'According to the ÖHV, this is "too little to make money."']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: "Of course, there are still a few vacancies this season," confirms Beate Kassner, Managing Director of Zillertal Tourism.
simplified: "Of course, there are still a few vacancies this season," says Zillertal Tourism managing director Beate Kassner.
split: ['"Of course, there are still a few vacancies this season," says Zillertal Tourism managing director Beate Kassner.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: Nevertheless, she says, they are pleased with the booking situation.
simplified: However, she said, they are happy with the booking situation.
split: ['However, she said, they are happy with the booking situation.']

label: dw-skiomicron-en.txt
original: In the Alpine region, the hope is that business will pick up in February — even though Austria has once again been declared a high-risk area.
simplified: In the Alpine region, the hope is that business will pick up in February. Austria has been declared a high-risk area once again.
split: ['In the Alpine region, the hope is that business will pick up in February', 'Austria has been declared a high-risk area once again.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: Far out in the ocean, where the water is as blue as the prettiest cornflower, and as clear as crystal, it is very, very deep; so deep, indeed, that no cable could fathom it: many church steeples, piled one upon another, would not reach from the ground beneath to the surface of the water above.
simplified: Far out in the ocean, where the water is as blue as the prettiest cornflower, and as clear as crystal, it is very, very deep; many church steeples would not reach from the ground beneath to the surface of the water above, because the water is too deep.
split: ['Far out in the ocean, where the water is as blue as the prettiest cornflower, and as clear as crystal, it is very, very deep; many church steeples would not reach from the ground beneath to the surface of the water above, because the water is too deep.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: There dwell the Sea King and his subjects.
simplified: The sea king and his people live there.
split: ['The sea king and his people live there.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: We must not imagine that there is nothing at the bottom of the sea but bare yellow sand.
simplified: We should not think that the sea bottom has nothing but bare yellow sand.
split: ['We should not think that the sea bottom has nothing but bare yellow sand.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: No, indeed; the most singular flowers and plants grow there; the leaves and stems of which are so pliant, that the slightest agitation of the water causes them to stir as if they had life.
simplified: No, indeed; the most singular flowers and plants grow there. The leaves and stems are so strong that when the water touches them, they stir as if they were alive.
split: ['No, indeed; the most singular flowers and plants grow there', 'The leaves and stems are so strong that when the water touches them, they stir as if they were alive.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: Fishes, both large and small, glide between the branches, as birds fly among the trees here upon land.
simplified: Fishes, both large and small, glide between the branches. There are also birds in the trees.
split: ['Fishes, both large and small, glide between the branches', 'There are also birds in the trees.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: In the deepest spot of all, stands the castle of the Sea King.
simplified: In the deepest place, the Sea King's castle can be found.
split: ["In the deepest place, the Sea King's castle can be found."]

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: Its walls are built of coral, and the long, gothic windows are of the clearest amber.
simplified: Its walls are made of coral. Its long, gothic windows are made of clear amber.
split: ['Its walls are made of coral', 'Its long, gothic windows are made of clear amber.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: The roof is formed of shells, that open and close as the water flows over them.
simplified: The roof is made of shells. When the water flows over them, they open and close.
split: ['The roof is made of shells', 'When the water flows over them, they open and close.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: Their appearance is very beautiful, for in each lies a glittering pearl, which would be fit for the diadem of a queen.
simplified: Their appearance is very beautiful. In each of them is a beautiful pearl. This pearl would be perfect for a queen.
split: ['Their appearance is very beautiful', 'In each of them is a beautiful pearl', 'This pearl would be perfect for a queen.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: The Sea King had been a widower for many years, and his aged mother kept house for him.
simplified: The Sea King had been a widower for many years. His mother kept the house for him.
split: ['The Sea King had been a widower for many years', 'His mother kept the house for him.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: She was a very wise woman, and exceedingly proud of her high birth; on that account she wore twelve oysters on her tail; while others, also of high rank, were only allowed to wear six.
simplified: She was a very wise woman, and very proud of her high birth. Because of this, she was allowed to wear twelve oysters on her tail, while others were only allowed six.
split: ['She was a very wise woman, and very proud of her high birth', 'Because of this, she was allowed to wear twelve oysters on her tail, while others were only allowed six.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: She was, however, deserving of very great praise, especially for her care of the little sea-princesses, her grand-daughters.
simplified: However, she was given a lot of praise because she took good care of her grand-daughters, the little sea-princesses.
split: ['However, she was given a lot of praise because she took good care of her grand-daughters, the little sea-princesses.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: They were six beautiful children; but the youngest was the prettiest of them all; her skin was as clear and delicate as a rose-leaf, and her eyes as blue as the deepest sea; but, like all the others, she had no feet, and her body ended in a fish’s tail.
simplified: They were all very beautiful, but the youngest was the most beautiful. Her skin was like a rose leaf, and her eyes were as blue as the deepest sea. But like all the others, she had no feet, and her body ended in a fish's tail.
split: ['They were all very beautiful, but the youngest was the most beautiful', 'Her skin was like a rose leaf, and her eyes were as blue as the deepest sea', "But like all the others, she had no feet, and her body ended in a fish's tail."]

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: All day long they played in the great halls of the castle, or among the living flowers that grew out of the walls.
simplified: They played all day long in the castle's great halls. They also played with the living flowers on the walls.
split: ["They played all day long in the castle's great halls", 'They also played with the living flowers on the walls.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: The large amber windows were open, and the fish swam in, just as the swallows fly into our houses when we open the windows, excepting that the fishes swam up to the princesses, ate out of their hands, and allowed themselves to be stroked.
simplified: The large amber windows were open, and the fish swam in, just as the swallows fly into our houses when we open the windows, except that the fish did not touch the princesses and did not eat from their hands.
split: ['The large amber windows were open, and the fish swam in, just as the swallows fly into our houses when we open the windows, except that the fish did not touch the princesses and did not eat from their hands.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: Outside the castle there was a beautiful garden, in which grew bright red and dark blue flowers, and blossoms like flames of fire; the fruit glittered like gold, and the leaves and stems waved to and fro continually.
simplified: There was a beautiful garden outside the castle. It had bright red and dark blue flowers, and blossoms like fire. The fruit looked like gold, and the leaves and stems moved from side to side.
split: ['There was a beautiful garden outside the castle', 'It had bright red and dark blue flowers, and blossoms like fire', 'The fruit looked like gold, and the leaves and stems moved from side to side.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: The earth itself was the finest sand, but blue as the flame of burning sulphur.
simplified: The earth itself was the best sand, but the blue of the fire was the best sand.
split: ['The earth itself was the best sand, but the blue of the fire was the best sand.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: Over everything lay a peculiar blue radiance, as if it were surrounded by the air from above, through which the blue sky shone, instead of the dark depths of the sea.
simplified: There was a strange blue light over everything, as if it were coming from above. The blue sky shone through it, instead of the dark depths of the sea.
split: ['There was a strange blue light over everything, as if it were coming from above', 'The blue sky shone through it, instead of the dark depths of the sea.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: In calm weather the sun could be seen, looking like a purple flower, with the light streaming from the calyx. Each of the young princesses had a little plot of ground in the garden, where she might dig and plant as she pleased.
simplified: In calm weather the sun could be seen, looking like a purple flower, with the light streaming from the calyx. Each of the young princesses had a garden of her own, where she could plant whatever she wanted.
split: ['In calm weather the sun could be seen, looking like a purple flower, with the light streaming from the calyx', 'Each of the young princesses had a garden of her own, where she could plant whatever she wanted.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: One arranged her flower-bed into the form of a whale; another thought it better to make hers like the figure of a little mermaid; but that of the youngest was round like the sun, and contained flowers as red as his rays at sunset.
simplified: One made her flower-bed in the shape of a whale, and another made her flower-bed like a little mermaid. The youngest flower-bed was round like the sun, and when the sun went down it had red flowers.
split: ['One made her flower-bed in the shape of a whale, and another made her flower-bed like a little mermaid', 'The youngest flower-bed was round like the sun, and when the sun went down it had red flowers.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: She was a strange child, quiet and thoughtful; and while her sisters would be delighted with the wonderful things which they obtained from the wrecks of vessels, she cared for nothing but her pretty red flowers, like the sun, excepting a beautiful marble statue.
simplified: She was a strange child, quiet and thoughtful. While her sisters were happy with all the beautiful things they had found when they searched for ships, she only cared for her pretty red flowers, like the sun, except for a beautiful statue.
split: ['She was a strange child, quiet and thoughtful', 'While her sisters were happy with all the beautiful things they had found when they searched for ships, she only cared for her pretty red flowers, like the sun, except for a beautiful statue.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: It was the representation of a handsome boy, carved out of pure white stone, which had fallen to the bottom of the sea from a wreck.
simplified: The picture showed a young boy who had been carved out of pure white stone. The stone had fallen to the bottom of the sea.
split: ['The picture showed a young boy who had been carved out of pure white stone', 'The stone had fallen to the bottom of the sea.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: She planted by the statue a rose-colored weeping willow.
simplified: A rose-colored weeping willow was planted near the statue.
split: ['A rose-colored weeping willow was planted near the statue.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: It grew splendidly, and very soon hung its fresh branches over the statue, almost down to the blue sands.
simplified: It grew very quickly. Soon its branches were almost all the way down to the blue sands.
split: ['It grew very quickly', 'Soon its branches were almost all the way down to the blue sands.']

label: andersen-mermaid-en.txt
original: The shadow had a violet tint, and waved to and fro like the branches; it seemed as if the crown of the tree and the root were at play, and trying to kiss each other.
simplified: The shadow had a violet color, and moved from side to side like the branches. It seemed like the tree's crown and root were trying to kiss each other.
split: ['The shadow had a violet color, and moved from side to side like the branches', "It seemed like the tree's crown and root were trying to kiss each other."]

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Coreference resolution systems typically operate by making sequences of local decisions (e.g., adding a coreference link between two mentions).
simplified: Coreference resolution systems typically operate by making local decisions (for example, adding a link between two pages).
split: ['Coreference resolution systems typically operate by making local decisions (for example, adding a link between two pages).']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: However, most measures of coreference resolution performance do not decompose over local decisions, which means the utility of a particular decision is not known until all other decisions have been made.
simplified: However, most measures of resolution performance do not take into account local decisions. This means that until all other decisions have been made, a particular decision is not known.
split: ['However, most measures of resolution performance do not take into account local decisions', 'This means that until all other decisions have been made, a particular decision is not known.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Due to this difficulty, coreference systems are usually trained with loss functions that heuristically define the goodness of a particular coreference decision.
simplified: Because of this, coreference systems are usually trained with loss functions to tell them how good a decision is when it is actually made.
split: ['Because of this, coreference systems are usually trained with loss functions to tell them how good a decision is when it is actually made.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: These losses contain hyperparameters that are carefully selected to ensure the model performs well according to coreference evaluation metrics.
simplified: These losses contain carefully selected hyperparameters to ensure that the model performs well according to the evaluation criteria.
split: ['These losses contain carefully selected hyperparameters to ensure that the model performs well according to the evaluation criteria.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: This complicates training, especially across different languages and datasets where systems may work best with different settings of the hyperparameters.
simplified: This makes training more complex, especially when different languages and data are used. Different systems work best with different settings.
split: ['This makes training more complex, especially when different languages and data are used', 'Different systems work best with different settings.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: To address this, we explore using two variants of reinforcement learning to directly optimize a coreference system for coreference evaluation metrics.
simplified: To address this, we use two variants of reinforcement learning to directly optimize a coreference system to provide better performance.
split: ['To address this, we use two variants of reinforcement learning to directly optimize a coreference system to provide better performance.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: In particular, we modify the max-margin coreference objective proposed by Wiseman et al. (2015) by incorporating the reward associated with each coreference decision into the loss’s slack rescaling.
simplified: In particular, we modify the max-margin coreference objective proposed by Wiseman et al. (2015) by including the loss's slack rescaling into the reward associated with each coreference decision.
split: ['In particular, we modify the max-margin coreference objective proposed by Wiseman et al', "(2015) by including the loss's slack rescaling into the reward associated with each coreference decision."]

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: We also test the REINFORCE policy gradient algorithm.
simplified: The policy gradient algorithm is also tested.
split: ['The policy gradient algorithm is also tested.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Our model is a neural mention-ranking model.
simplified: Our model is a neural ranking model.
split: ['Our model is a neural ranking model.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Mention-ranking models score pairs of mentions for their likelihood of coreference rather than comparing partial coreference clusters.
simplified: Mention-ranking models score pairs of mentions according to their likelihood (how likely they are to do something).
split: ['Mention-ranking models score pairs of mentions according to their likelihood (how likely they are to do something).']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Hence they operate in a simple setting where coreference decisions are made independently.
simplified: Therefore, they work in a simple setting, and decisions are made independently.
split: ['Therefore, they work in a simple setting, and decisions are made independently.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Although they are less expressive than entity-centric approaches to coreference, mention-ranking models are fast, scalable, and simple to train, causing them to be the dominant approach to coreference in recent years.
simplified: Although mention-ranking models are less expressive than entity-centric approaches to coreference, mention-ranking models are fast, scalable, and simple to train, and have become the dominant approach to coreference.
split: ['Although mention-ranking models are less expressive than entity-centric approaches to coreference, mention-ranking models are fast, scalable, and simple to train, and have become the dominant approach to coreference.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Having independent actions is particularly useful when applying reinforcement learning because it means a particular action’s effect on the final reward can be computed efficiently.
simplified: Having independent actions is particularly useful when learning how to use reinforcement learning. It means that an action can be used to calculate the final reward.
split: ['Having independent actions is particularly useful when learning how to use reinforcement learning', 'It means that an action can be used to calculate the final reward.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: We evaluate the models on the English and Chinese portions of the CoNLL 2012 Shared Task.
simplified: The English and Chinese versions of the CoNLL 2012 shared task are evaluated.
split: ['The English and Chinese versions of the CoNLL 2012 shared task are evaluated.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: The REINFORCE algorithm is competitive with a heuristic loss function while the reward-rescaled objective significantly outperforms both.
simplified: The REINFORCE algorithm is competitive with a heuristic loss function. The reward-rescaled objective is significantly better.
split: ['The REINFORCE algorithm is competitive with a heuristic loss function', 'The reward-rescaled objective is significantly better.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: We attribute this to reward rescaling being well suited for a ranking task due to its max-margin loss as well as benefiting from directly optimizing for coreference metrics.
simplified: We attribute this to reward rescaling being well suited for a ranking task as well as directly optimizing for coreference metrics due to its max-margin loss.
split: ['We attribute this to reward rescaling being well suited for a ranking task as well as directly optimizing for coreference metrics due to its max-margin loss.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Error analysis shows that using the reward-rescaling loss results in a similar number of mistakes as the heuristic loss, but the mistakes tend to be less severe.
simplified: Error analysis shows that using the reward-rescaling loss results in the same number of errors, but the number of errors are less severe.
split: ['Error analysis shows that using the reward-rescaling loss results in the same number of errors, but the number of errors are less severe.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: We use the neural mention-ranking model described in Clark and Manning (2016), which we briefly go over in this section.
simplified: We use the neural mention-ranking model described in Clark and Manning (2016) in this section, for example.
split: ['We use the neural mention-ranking model described in Clark and Manning (2016) in this section, for example.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Given a mention m and candidate antecedent c, the mention-ranking model produces a score for the pair s(c, m) indicating their compatibility for coreference with a feedforward neural network.
simplified: Given a mention m and a candidate antecedent c, the model gives a score to each pair. The score of the pair s(c, m) tells us if they are compatible with each other.
split: ['Given a mention m and a candidate antecedent c, the model gives a score to each pair', 'The score of the pair s(c, m) tells us if they are compatible with each other.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: The candidate antecedent may be any mention that occurs before m in the document or NA, indicating that m has no antecedent.
simplified: The candidate antecedent may be any mention of m in the document. The antecedent may be before m, but after m.
split: ['The candidate antecedent may be any mention of m in the document', 'The antecedent may be before m, but after m.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: For each mention, the model extracts various words (e.g., the mention’s head word) and groups of words (e.g., all words in the mention’s sentence) that are fed into the neural network.
simplified: For each sentence, the model extracts various words (e.g., the sentence name) and groups of words (e.g., the head word) that are fed into the neural network.
split: ['For each sentence, the model extracts various words (e.g., the sentence name) and groups of words (e.g., the head word) that are fed into the neural network.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Each word is represented by a vector wi ∈ Rdw.
simplified: Each letter is represented by a vector (a number).
split: ['Each letter is represented by a vector (a number).']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: Each group of words is represented by the average of the vectors of each word in the group.
simplified: Each group of words is represented by a vector, and each word in the group is represented by a dot.
split: ['Each group of words is represented by a vector, and each word in the group is represented by a dot.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: In addition to the embeddings, a small number of additional features are used, including distance, string matching, and speaker identification features.
simplified: In addition to the embeddings, a small number of additional features are used, including speaker identification and string matching.
split: ['In addition to the embeddings, a small number of additional features are used, including speaker identification and string matching.']

label: paper-clarkmanning2016-en.txt
original: See Clark and Manning (2016) for the full set of features and an ablation study.
simplified: See Clark and Manning (2016) for an ablation study and the full set of features.
split: ['See Clark and Manning (2016) for an ablation study and the full set of features.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Speech recognition is invading our lives.
simplified: Speech recognition is changing our lives.
split: ['Speech recognition is changing our lives.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: It’s built into our phones, our game consoles and our smart watches.
simplified: They are built into our phones, smart watches, and game consoles.
split: ['They are built into our phones, smart watches, and game consoles.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: It’s even automating our homes.
simplified: Even our homes are being automated.
split: ['Even our homes are being automated.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: For just $50, you can get an Amazon Echo Dot — a magic box that allows you to order pizza, get a weather report or even buy trash bags — just by speaking out loud.
simplified: For just $50, you can get an Amazon Echo Dot, a magic box that allows you to buy trash bags, get a weather report and order pizza just by speaking out loud.
split: ['For just $50, you can get an Amazon Echo Dot, a magic box that allows you to buy trash bags, get a weather report and order pizza just by speaking out loud.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: The Echo Dot has been so popular this holiday season that Amazon can’t seem to keep them in stock!
simplified: The Echo Dot has been so popular this holiday season that Amazon has not been able to keep it in stock.
split: ['The Echo Dot has been so popular this holiday season that Amazon has not been able to keep it in stock.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: But speech recognition has been around for decades, so why is it just now hitting the mainstream?
simplified: But speech recognition has been around for a long time, so why is it just now being used?
split: ['But speech recognition has been around for a long time, so why is it just now being used?']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: The reason is that deep learning finally made speech recognition accurate enough to be useful outside of carefully controlled environments.
simplified: The reason for this is that deep learning finally made speech recognition accurate enough to be used outside of training environments.
split: ['The reason for this is that deep learning finally made speech recognition accurate enough to be used outside of training environments.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Andrew Ng has long predicted that as speech recognition goes from 95% accurate to 99% accurate, it will become a primary way that we interact with computers.
simplified: Andrew Ng has said for a long time that when speech recognition goes from 95% accurate to 99% accurate, we will use computers more and more.
split: ['Andrew Ng has said for a long time that when speech recognition goes from 95% accurate to 99% accurate, we will use computers more and more.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: The idea is that this 4% accuracy gap is the difference between annoyingly unreliable and incredibly useful.
simplified: The idea is that this 4% difference is the difference between very useful and very unreliable.
split: ['The idea is that this 4% difference is the difference between very useful and very unreliable.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Thanks to Deep Learning, we’re finally cresting that peak.
simplified: Deep learning has finally reached its peak.
split: ['Deep learning has finally reached its peak.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Let’s learn how to do speech recognition with deep learning!
simplified: Let's take a look at speech recognition with deep learning.
split: ["Let's take a look at speech recognition with deep learning."]

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Machine Learning isn’t always a Black Box.
simplified: Machine learning is not always a bad thing.
split: ['Machine learning is not always a bad thing.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: If you know how neural machine translation works, you might guess that we could simply feed sound recordings into a neural network and train it to produce text.
simplified: If you know how neural machine translation works, you might think that we could simply feed a neural network sound recordings and train it to create text.
split: ['If you know how neural machine translation works, you might think that we could simply feed a neural network sound recordings and train it to create text.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: That’s the holy grail of speech recognition with deep learning, but we aren’t quite there yet (at least at the time that I wrote this — I bet that we will be in a couple of years).
simplified: This is the holy grail of deep learning speech recognition, but we are not quite there yet (at least not yet). I bet that we will be in a couple of years (at least).
split: ['This is the holy grail of deep learning speech recognition, but we are not quite there yet (at least not yet)', 'I bet that we will be in a couple of years (at least).']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: The big problem is that speech varies in speed.
simplified: The main problem is that the speed varies.
split: ['The main problem is that the speed varies.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: One person might say “hello!” very quickly and another person might say “heeeelllllllllllllooooo!” very slowly, producing a much longer sound file with much more data.
simplified: One person might say "hello" very quickly, and the other person might say "heeeelllllllllllllooooo" very slowly. This will make a longer sound file.
split: ['One person might say "hello" very quickly, and the other person might say "heeeelllllllllllllooooo" very slowly', 'This will make a longer sound file.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Both both sound files should be recognized as exactly the same text — “hello!”
simplified: Both both sound files should be recognized as the same sound file.
split: ['Both both sound files should be recognized as the same sound file.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Automatically aligning audio files of various lengths to a fixed-length piece of text turns out to be pretty hard.
simplified: Automatically aligning different length audio files to a given piece of text turns out to be quite hard.
split: ['Automatically aligning different length audio files to a given piece of text turns out to be quite hard.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: To work around this, we have to use some special tricks and extra precessing in addition to a deep neural network.
simplified: To work around this, we need to use some special tricks and more processing as well as a deep neural network.
split: ['To work around this, we need to use some special tricks and more processing as well as a deep neural network.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Let’s see how it works!
simplified: Let us see how it works.
split: ['Let us see how it works.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: The first step in speech recognition is obvious — we need to feed sound waves into a computer.
simplified: The first step in speech recognition is obvious. A computer needs to be fed sound waves.
split: ['The first step in speech recognition is obvious', 'A computer needs to be fed sound waves.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: In Part 3, we learned how to take an image and treat it as an array of numbers so that we can feed directly into a neural network for image recognition.
simplified: In Part 3, we learned how to take an image and treat it as an array of numbers so that a neural network can be fed directly into it.
split: ['In Part 3, we learned how to take an image and treat it as an array of numbers so that a neural network can be fed directly into it.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: But sound is transmitted as waves.
simplified: The sound is sent out as waves.
split: ['The sound is sent out as waves.']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: How do we turn sound waves into numbers?
simplified: How do numbers turn into sound waves?
split: ['How do numbers turn into sound waves?']

label: popsciblog-moisfun6-en.txt
original: Let’s use this sound clip of me saying “Hello”.
simplified: For example, let's use this sound clip.
split: ["For example, let's use this sound clip."]

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: At the center of Earth sits the planet's fiery core, which scientists say might be losing heat faster than expected.
simplified: At the center of Earth is the planet's hot core. Scientists say the core may be losing heat faster than expected.
split: ["At the center of Earth is the planet's hot core", 'Scientists say the core may be losing heat faster than expected.']

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: Earth's core has been cooling since the planet formed some 4.5 billion years ago, when the entire surface was covered with oceans of magma.
simplified: The Earth's core has been cooling since the planet formed. When the Earth was first made, the entire surface was covered with magma.
split: ["The Earth's core has been cooling since the planet formed", 'When the Earth was first made, the entire surface was covered with magma.']

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: Scientific understanding of how quickly this cooling occurs was challenged in a study published January 15 that suggests the process is moving much faster than scientists thought.
simplified: The scientific understanding of how quickly this cooling happens was challenged on January 15. A study showed that the process may be going faster than scientists thought.
split: ['The scientific understanding of how quickly this cooling happens was challenged on January 15', 'A study showed that the process may be going faster than scientists thought.']

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: The discovery, by researchers from Switzerland, Germany, the US and Japan, adds to a body of research that supports the idea that radiation plays a bigger role in heat extraction from the Earth's core than once assumed.
simplified: The discovery, by researchers from Switzerland, Germany, the US and Japan, adds to a body of research that has shown that more heat comes from the Earth's core than was thought before.
split: ["The discovery, by researchers from Switzerland, Germany, the US and Japan, adds to a body of research that has shown that more heat comes from the Earth's core than was thought before."]

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: The core-mantle boundary lies between the Earth's lower mantle and its liquid core.
simplified: The Earth's lower mantle is made up of rock, and its upper mantle is liquid.
split: ["The Earth's lower mantle is made up of rock, and its upper mantle is liquid."]

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: Scientists believe it is largely composed of a mineral called bridgmanite, characterized and named after physicist Percy Bridgman in 2014.
simplified: It is made up mostly of a mineral called bridgmanite. The mineral was named after physicist Percy Bridgman in 2014.
split: ['It is made up mostly of a mineral called bridgmanite', 'The mineral was named after physicist Percy Bridgman in 2014.']

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: Scientists consider bridgmanite the most abundant mineral on the planet.
simplified: Bridgmanite is the most common mineral in the world.
split: ['Bridgmanite is the most common mineral in the world.']

label: dw-earth-en.txt
original: "We eventually found that the previous thermal conductivity value [of bridgmanite] was highly underestimated," said Motohiko Murakami, an earth sciences professor at ETH Zurich and lead author of the study.
simplified: "We eventually found that the previous thermal conductivity value [of bridgmanite] was highly underestimated," said Motohiko Murakami, lead author of the study and a professor at ETH Zurich.
